- neutron http://cloudbase-ci.com/neutron/612153/16 : SUCCESS in 1h 34m 21s'}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2018-12-05 22:08:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: -Code-Review

I think my only concern with this patch is that the logging that occurs is less verbose than we get from the current ovsdb-client monitor functionality.  Currently we will get the full JSON representation from ovsdb-client monitor of the bridge event being detected [1] whereas based on the logs I am seeing from the functional tests introduced in this change it looks like there is considerably less information returned [2]. 

I think it would be a really good idea to add information for BridgeCreateEvents and BridgeDeleteEvents that shows the bridge name, MAC, and perhaps also associated trunk names, when applicable.

I could see this as a follow-on change so not downvoting this change. 

[1] for example http://logs.openstack.org/28/585028/26/gate/neutron-functional/882ff6e/logs/dsvm-functional-logs/neutron.tests.functional.services.trunk.drivers.openvswitch.agent.test_ovsdb_handler.OVSDBHandlerTestCase.test_trunk_creation_with_subports.txt.gz#_2018-11-30_21_29_24_807
[2] http://logs.openstack.org/53/612153/16/gate/neutron-functional/b2986fb/logs/dsvm-functional-logs/neutron.tests.functional.agent.ovsdb.native.test_connection.BridgeMonitorTestCase.test_create_bridges.txt.gz#_2018-12-05_12_41_31_576'}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2018-12-06 09:11:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

commit_message:
Add native OVSDB implementation for bridge monitor

This patch implements an OVS bridge monitor based in the OVSDB
native implementation (OVSDB IDL, Open vSwitch Database Interface
Definition Language). This new implementation supersedes the CLI
OVSDB monitor.

Partial-Bug: #1789592

Change-Id: I9c512d4cbd4cebf94c339231f83bbe89b37650ba

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-05 14:57:25.000000000', 'message': 'add a house rule for the release-management key in projects.yaml

The release-management metadata for a project is managed by the release
team. This change applies the same delegation rules that we use for the
delegated tags that the stable and VMT teams use.

Change-Id: Ib47f9c569376ef13267342a47600b53007213fb9
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
'}]
commit_message:
add a house rule for the release-management key in projects.yaml

The release-management metadata for a project is managed by the release
team. This change applies the same delegation rules that we use for the
delegated tags that the stable and VMT teams use.

Change-Id: Ib47f9c569376ef13267342a47600b53007213fb9
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Update min tox version to 2.0

The commands used by constraints need at least tox 2.0.  Update to
reflect reality, which should help with local running of constraints
targets.

Change-Id: I04c5076090edcced92ca08bbdbe8e3a7cb239e53

commit_message:
Add docs for (initial) allocation ratio configuration

This adds a new section to the admin scheduler configuration
docs devoted to allocation ratios to call out the differences
between the override config options and the initial ratio
options, and how they interplay with the resource provider
inventory allocation ratio override that can be performed
via the placement REST API directly.

This moves the note about bug 1804125 into the new section
and also links to the docs from the initial allocation ratio
config option help text.

Part of blueprint initial-allocation-ratios
Related-Bug: #1804125

Change-Id: I7d8e822cd40dccaf5244e2cd95fa1af43fa9ed87

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-09 17:05:39.000000000', 'message': 'fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: Ic9990c5fbef429bb013d0c0c83aea508409c0f6d
'}]
commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: Ic9990c5fbef429bb013d0c0c83aea508409c0f6d

check experimental'}, {'account_id': 11600, 'date': '2018-12-06 12:22:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 21041, 'date': '2018-12-06 13:05:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 21041, 'date': '2018-12-06 15:03:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 21041, 'date': '2018-12-06 15:20:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 21041, 'date': '2018-12-06 16:07:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 21041, 'date': '2018-12-06 20:53:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 14352, 'date': '2018-12-07 07:37:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

I like this effort at reducing flakiness. I wonder though if we should, as this patch proposes, implicitly tolerate that a curl that reaches a backend that already worked, fails afterwards.

Let's say the curl is to service A, which has two pods (1 and 2). I expect that the errors you are tolerating here are due to the service responding because one of the pods is ready while the other is not, but eventually needing both to respond for the test to pass. What I'm saying is that it would leave much less room for false positives if we only allowed failure if once both A.1 and A.2 respond correctly, we do not tolerate any more parse exceptions."}, {'account_id': 21041, 'date': '2018-12-09 15:13:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 21041, 'date': '2018-12-09 15:18:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 21041, 'date': '2018-12-10 07:24:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

@Toni,
I sent [1] patch, that will mark service as 'ready to test' only after all we received a response from all pods using the service's IP.
I'd changed this patch just to log info in case of an exception.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/623926/"}, {'account_id': 23567, 'date': '2018-12-10 09:33:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 14352, 'date': '2018-12-10 13:46:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

test results we should log the exception and continue with the test.

[1] File "/usr/lib/python2.7/multiprocessing/pool.py", line 567, in get
    raise self._value
ValueError: invalid literal for int() with base 10: ''

Change-Id: I9aad5533120625530e74d627487caf7e262a30de
'}, {'created': '2018-12-06 09:16:04.000000000', 'message': 'Handle Exceptions in multi-threaded connectivity test

In the multi-threaded connectivity tests, we run the test 100
times.
In current code, if one of the tests fail we report the whole
test as a failure.

This patch changes this behavior, in case one the tests fail
(due to [1] and [2] for example) it will log the error and
continue with the tests.

commit_message:
Allocate service FIP after LB was provisioned

This patch changes the FIP allocation to be only
after all LB components were provisioned.

With this approach, the FIP allocation is performed just before
Kuryr annotates endpoints details, this should reduce
the probability for orphan FIPs in case of kuryr-controller
restart.

In addition it updates FIP allocation to check if FIP
already allocated for LB vip before allocating new FIP.

Change-Id: Idb734f81a1f4fc60155b0700de275d0b01f52a30
Closes-Bug: 1806647
(cherry picked from commit 300dc36b062aaa2c5eb1c3ee2f8c041e1e33a99d)

commit_message:
use include_tasks instead of include

include is marked as deprecated since ansible 2.4[0]

Switch to include_tasks or import_playbook as necessary

[0] https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/2.4/include_module.html#deprecated

Change-Id: I5b9e7be4c7212e3c483d2c65746629416cd309f2

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-02 19:16:23.000000000', 'message': "Use a common python build/install role

In order to radically simplify how we prepare the service
venvs, we use a common role to do the wheel builds and the
venv preparation. This makes the process far simpler to
understand, because the role does its own building and
installing. It also reduces the code maintenance burden,
because instead of duplicating the build processes in the
repo_build role and the service role - we only have it all
done in a single place.

We also change the role venv tag var to use the integrated
build's common venv tag so that we can remove the role's
venv tag in group_vars in the integrated build. This reduces
memory consumption and also reduces the duplication.

This is by no means the final stop in the simplification
process, but it is a step forward. The will be work to follow
which:

1. Replaces 'developer mode' with an equivalent mechanism
   that uses the common role and is simpler to understand.
   We will also simplify the provisioning of pip install
   arguments when doing this.
2. Simplifies the installation of optional pip packages.
   Right now it's more complicated than it needs to be due
   to us needing to keep the py_pkgs plugin working in the
   integrated build.
3. Deduplicates the distro package installs. Right now the
   role installs the distro packages twice - just before
   building the venv, and during the python_venv_build role
   execution.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/598957
Change-Id: Iecb64d28afe3acfbae7060af55c1a891310e5ef4
Implements: blueprint python-build-install-simplification
Signed-off-by: Jesse Pretorius <jesse.pretorius@rackspace.co.uk>

commit_message:
Use a common python build/install role

In order to radically simplify how we prepare the service
venvs, we use a common role to do the wheel builds and the
venv preparation. This makes the process far simpler to
understand, because the role does its own building and
installing. It also reduces the code maintenance burden,
because instead of duplicating the build processes in the
repo_build role and the service role - we only have it all
done in a single place.

We also change the role venv tag var to use the integrated
build's common venv tag so that we can remove the role's
venv tag in group_vars in the integrated build. This reduces
memory consumption and also reduces the duplication.

This is by no means the final stop in the simplification
process, but it is a step forward. The will be work to follow
which:

1. Replaces 'developer mode' with an equivalent mechanism
   that uses the common role and is simpler to understand.
   We will also simplify the provisioning of pip install
   arguments when doing this.
2. Simplifies the installation of optional pip packages.
   Right now it's more complicated than it needs to be due
   to us needing to keep the py_pkgs plugin working in the
   integrated build.
3. Deduplicates the distro package installs. Right now the
   role installs the distro packages twice - just before
   building the venv, and during the python_venv_build role
   execution.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/598957
Change-Id: Iecb64d28afe3acfbae7060af55c1a891310e5ef4
Implements: blueprint python-build-install-simplification
Signed-off-by: Jesse Pretorius <jesse.pretorius@rackspace.co.uk>

commit_message:
Include ansible-role-redhat-subscription in base image

ansible-role-redhat-subscription rpm is needed on the overcloud images
when we will run Ansible to unsubscribe the nodes on the overcloud.
it's also needed in Queens where Ansible is run by Heat on localhost
mode.

Change-Id: I18e2bde1e20a9eb1840b237b840b407ecf1641cd
Closes-Bug: #1807025
